title: My daughter is 4.5 years old. How can I prepare her for Olympiad exams? - Quora

response.answer_text: Your daughter is a sprout. You understandably want to nurture her into a tall, strong, and healthy oak prepared for the challenges of life. The flaw is your daughter may not be an oak. She may be a palm tree. Or a rose bush. If you prepare her to become an oak, she will not only not be an oak but she’ll be a sickly rose bush. The kids who make it at the Olympiads are oaks. Their parents recognized their oakness and fed them what oaks need to grow mighty. Your role as a parent isn’t to nurture oaks. It is to discover what kind of sprout your child is and provide what that sprout needs. She is showing you what kind of sprout she is right now. What children are drawn provides little windows inside. She may love to move her body. Or she may love puzzles. Or she may love people, animals, stories, singing, growing things, drawing. Your role is to honor the sprout she is, not show her that your love and approval is contingent on her being the kind of sprout you think is best. Give her more of what she loves, even if you don’t see the value in it. She’s 4. She needs what feeds a 4 year old, not what feels satisfying to an adult. If it’s a cartoon, or chasing the dog, or dancing to music that’s what she needs. Give her what connects to what she loves. Open doors and build bridges out into the world from where she is. Let her choose to explore or not. Let her know what’s there. Take her new places and expose her to new things. She can’t know what she loves until she’s seen it. But let her enjoyment be your guide. If she’s not engaged, she’s not learning. If she’s pushed, she’ll pull back and associate the activity with being pushed. Let her choose. If she’s an oak, she’ll be prepared for Olympiads because that’s who she is. She’ll be doing what fascinates and challenges her. If she’s not an oak, she’ll be prepared for who ever she is by being supported in following what engages and challenges her. It won’t be Olympiads but it will be something she’s uniquely good at. The question is, will that be good enough for you? Or do you need an Olympiad daughter to feel you’re a good parent?

Please don’t, until or if she indicates that she wants to compete academically against other kids. The world doesn’t need more hyper-competitive, overly-prepped people who can’t function without someone scheduling their every moment or pushing them toward a specific goal that they themselves did not choose. I’m not saying that you’re there yet, but it sounds like you’re considering starting down that path. Please just don’t. We know kids - my kids have friends and classmates - who have little to no free time, who don’t get to choose their own activities based on their own interests, who aren’t allowed to play with friends or go to birthday parties or just chill and be kids because their parents want them studying and training all the time. These kids are stressed, anxious, and miserable. There’s already a problem with kids in college, high school, and sometimes even middle school killing themselves because they’re under such tremendous pressure and cannot handle it. Our job as parents is to produce children who grow up to be healthy, productive, functional, and hopefully happy and interesting adults. If they aren’t those things, how will they be dealing out in the world on their own?
